Manx: Mannin veg veen ayns yn aarkey ny lomarcan,
English: Dear Mannin alone in the ocean,
Diplomatic: Mannin veg veen ayns yn aarkey ny lomyrken

Manx: Ta soar millish connee goll nish lesh-ny-geayee,
English: A sweet smell of heather goes now with the wind,
Diplomatic: Ta soar millish connee goll nish lesh ny gheayee

Manx: Ta’n niarragh er jeet lesh frassyn as summarkyn,
English: The spring has come with showers and primroses,
Diplomatic: Ta’n niarragh er jeet lesh frassyn as sommyrken

Manx: Ny croink ooilley coamrit lesh aittyn as freoagh.
English: The hills all covered with gorse and heather.
Diplomatic: Ny croink ooilley coamryt lesh ashyn as fraie

Manx: Ny sleityn ta coodit lesh bodjalyn baney
English: The mountains are covered with white clouds,
Diplomatic: Ny slityn ta coodyt lesh bodjalyn baaney

Manx: Dagh nhee ta goaill soylley jeh’n ghrain as yn çhiass
English: Each colour that enjoys the sun and the heat,
Diplomatic: Dagh nhee ta ghoaill solley jeh’n ghrain as yn chass

Manx: Ny lhontyn soilshean ayns nyn garmodyn geaney
English: The glens shining in their vivid green garments,
Diplomatic: Ny lhyntyn soljean ayns nyn garmodyn gheney
Notes: lhontyn — phonetic spelling of how glionteeyn ‘glens’ was likely pronounced in Cregneash in Ned Beg’s day.

Manx: As fynnyr beg cheet er voish yn sheerass
English: And a little breeze coming from the southwest.
Diplomatic: As fynnyr beg cheet er voish yn sheerass

Manx: Ny heirrinee tarroogh ta traaue ayns ny magheryn ,
English: The industrious farmers that plough in the fields,
Diplomatic: Ny errinee tarroog ta traue ayn ny maghryn

Manx: Cuirr arroo sy voghrey as soiagh potaase,
English: Sowing corn in the morning and planting potatoes,
Diplomatic: Quir arroo sy voghry as soiagh potaase

Manx: As gimman ny cabbil nagh jed ad er shaghryn,
English: And driving the horses so they won’t go astray,
Diplomatic: As gimman ny chabbyl nagh jed ad er shaghryn

Manx: Eisht jerkal rish frassyn dy chur orroo gaase.
English: Then hoping[1] for showers to make them grow.
Diplomatic: Esh jerkal rish fraasyn dy chur orroo gaase

Manx: Ta’n shellan beg hene ta rouaill fud ny blaaghyn,
English: Even the little bee that wanders through the blossoms,
Diplomatic: Tan shellan beg hene ta rouaill fud ny blaaghyn

Manx: Yn viljid te jiole as dagh pooishee ta mie,
English: The sweetness she sucks out of every flower that is good,
Diplomatic: Yn viljyg te jiole as dagh pushee ta mie

Manx: Gyn smooinaght er frassyn ny er ny shenn raaidyn,
English: Without thinking of showers or about the old ways,
Diplomatic: Gyn smoinagh er fraasyn ne er ny shen raaidyn

Manx: Gys laadit lesh miljey t’eh getlagh çheet thie.
English: Until loaded with sweetness he flies, going home.
Diplomatic: Gys loadyt lesh miljey te getlagh cheet thie

Manx: Ta’n niarragh er jeet nish lesh imbagh feer aalin,
English: The spring has now brought a very beautiful season,
Diplomatic: Tan niarragh er jeet nish lesh imbagh feer aalin

Manx: As pooisheeyn souree dy leah vees ayns blaa,
English: And summer flowers will soon be in flower,
Diplomatic: As pusheeyn souree dy leah vess ayns blaa

Manx: T’ad cowragh cloan veggey gaase seose ayns nyn aegid,
English: They signify little children growing up in their youth,
Diplomatic: T’ad cowragh chloan veggey gaase seose ayns nyn aagyd

Manx: Agh reesht gys yn joan myr yn pooishee çhyndaa.
English: But again to the dust, like the flower, return.
Diplomatic: Agh reesht gys yn joan myr yn pushee chyndaa.

Manx: Ta’n gollan geayee hene çheet veih çheeraghyn foddey,
English: Even the swallow comes from far (away) countries,
Diplomatic: Ta’n gollanghiye hene cheet veih cheeraghyn foddey

Manx: As troggal e hedd ayns ny follagheeyn thie,
English: And builds her nest in the house’s hiding places,
Diplomatic: As throggal y edd ayns ny fealaghyn thie
Notes: follagheeyn — likely folliaghtyn; ‘secrets’, ‘mysteries’, ‘abounding in motes’, etc.

Manx: Dy hirrey son beaghey t’ee girree dy moghey,
English: To search for food she rises early,
Diplomatic: Dy hirrey son beagey t’ee girree dy moghey

Manx: As amnagh syn astyr t’ee reesht goll dy lhie.
English: And late in the afternoon she goes back to bed.
Diplomatic: As amnagh syn astyr t’ee reesht gholl dy lhie

Manx: Ta’n ushag veg chabbagh troggal seose sy voghery,
English: The little lark gets up in the morning,
Diplomatic: Ta’n ushag veg chabbagh throggal seose sy voghey

Manx: As getlagh syn aer jannoo taitnys as kiaull,
English: And flies in the sky making fun and music,
Diplomatic: As getlagh syn aer jannoo taitnys as chiaull

Manx: Yn chooag er e heiyrt ta mennick cur doogh urree,
English: The cuckoo following her often upsets her,
Diplomatic: Yn chaulk er y iyrt ta mennick cur doogh urree

Manx: As geiyrt ee ersooyl foddey jeh veih e hoayll.
English: And drives her away, far from from her home.
Diplomatic: As guyrt ee ersooyl foddey jeh veih y oayll

Manx: Ny-yeih, ayns traa gerrid bee blaaghyn yn tourey,
English: Nevertheless, in a short time, the flowers of the summer will be,
Diplomatic: Ny-yeih ayn tra gherryd bee blaaghyn yn thourey

Manx: Ooilley floagit[4] ersooyl gyn unnane ny chooyl,
English: All atomized away, without one behind,
Diplomatic: Ooilley flogyt ersooyl gyn yn nane ny chooyl
Notes: floagit — likley derived from floag; ‘atom’, ‘dot’, ‘flake’, ‘particle’, floagid; ‘minuteness’ and floagagh; ‘having atoms’, ‘flakey’,

Manx: Son tra hig yn feayraght as sterrym sy yeurey,
English: For when the cold and storm and winter comes,
Diplomatic: Son tra hig yn feearagh as styrrym sy geurey

Manx: Nee sniaghtey as rio geiyrt ad ooilley ersooyl.
English: Snow and ice will chase them all away.
Diplomatic: Nee snaghtey as rio giyrt ad ooilley ersooyl

Manx: Myr pooisheeyn sourey ta aalid chloan gheiney,
English: Like summer flowers, is the beauty of mankind’s children,
Diplomatic: Myr pusheeyn sourey ta aalid chloan gheiney

Manx: Ta gaase seose dy siyragh agh leah t’ad caghlaa,
English: That grow up hurriedly, but soon they change,
Diplomatic: Ta gaase seose dy siyragh agh lheah tad caghlaa

Manx: Myr pooisheeyn aalin ta gaase ayns çhiass ghreiney,
English: Like beautiful flowers that grow in heat of the sun,
Diplomatic: Myr pusheeyn aalin ta gaase ayns chass ghrainey

Manx: Agh reesht gys yn joan nee mayd ooilley çhyndaa.
English: But we will all return again to the dust.
Diplomatic: Agh reesht gys yn joan nee mayd ooilley chindaa

Manx: Eisht lhig dooin nish çheet gys Chreest son saualtys,
English: Then let us now come to Christ for salvation,
Diplomatic: Esht lhig dooin nish cheet gys Chreest son saualtys

Manx: Dy vod mayd ve aarloo son dy bragh beayn,
English: So that we can be ready for ever eternal,
Diplomatic: Dy vod mayd ve aarloo son dy braagh beeayn

Manx: As gyn shooyl ny sodjey ayns raaidyn rouailtys,
English: And not walk any further in wandering ways,
Diplomatic: As gyn shooyl ny sodjey ayns raaidyn roualtys

Manx: Cosoylagh jeh faarkaghey boiragh yn cheayn.
English: Comparable to a troublesome swimmer of the sea.
Diplomatic: Chosolagh keh faarkaghy boiragh yn cheayn

Manx: Esiht lhig dooin çheet thie as gyn shooyl ayns yn aasagh,
English: Then, let us come home and not walk in the wilderness,
Diplomatic: Esht lhig dooin cheet thie as gyn shooyl ayns yn aasagh

Manx: As cur seose nyn accan gys Yeesey yn Çhiarn,
English: And give up our complaing to the Lord Jesus,
Diplomatic: As chur seose nyn accan gys Yeesey yn Chiarn

Manx: Ayns pastyryn geayney nee Eh shin y faasagh,
English: In green pastures he will pasture us,
Diplomatic: Ayns pastyryn gheney nee E shin y faasagh

Manx: Choud as ta’n gialdyn echey faagit er-mayrn.
English: As long as his promise remains.
Diplomatic: Choud as ta ghoaldyn eck E ffagyt ermarn

Manx: Edwd Faragher
English: Edwd Faragher
Diplomatic: Edwd Faragher

Manx: Blackwell Colliery, Derbyshire.
English: Blackwell Colliery, Derbyshire.
Diplomatic: Blackwell colliery Derbyshire
